title: The new TSM
body: So was the TSM roster for IEM just a trial roster? They had 3 players on the team from the EU region and LCS teams have to have 3 out of 5 players from the region they are playing in so one of them has to go right? Anyone know?

replies.body: Bjergson declared NA as his country of residence.  So he "moved" to NA and is now considered an NA player.  Hauntzer Sven and Dlift are confirmed to be on the TSM roster for next season.  kaSing is on a try out right now but he seems to like the team (click [here](https://twitter.com/kasinglol/status/668548179403517955)) )

1: LCS hasn't started yet, IEM doesn't have those rules (I think). 

2: Bjerg has lived in NA for 24 of the last 36 months. That qualifies him as an NA citizen for Riot. 
XiaoWeiXiao also was able to count as NA due to this clause.
For some reason Bjergsen counts as an NA player now so they only have Svenskeren and Kasing as EU players.  This will most likely be their final roster.
Bjergsen was recently "Grandfathered". He's been in NA for 2(?) years, and is now considered a legal NA citizen.
I believe he counts as having legal NA residency now or something like that
Doublelift said in an interview that Kasing was technically still on trial throughout IEM but that the other 4 were locked in.

Apparently Riot built a backdoor into its regional policies by allowing foreign players switch regions after a fairly short period of time. Fairly shortly we should have enough region switched players to have all EU or KR teams in NA.
2 lcs seasons is pretty short. It would also depend on the language, like can you seed other regional players onto your challenger series teams for two years and then bring them on as NA players?
how are 2 seasons short? there have only been 6 seasons so far...

Because it's exponential growth. Most NA LCS teams have at least two non-region players. Any of those players who spend two seasons in the NA LCS no longer count as non-regional. So every two years you could potentially have twenty new players, or enough to field four LCS teams, become 'naturalized' NA players.

Now, player changes happen too frequently in the LCS to make it probable that it will happen on that scale, but it would not be surprising if ~5 players get naturalized in this fashion every couple years. If they can use secondary squads to qualify for this time, then the growth could be much higher.

The reason this is even a concern is it allows a mechanism to defeat the out of region player limit's purpose in the first place: preserving regional identity for the fans. The moment there are no (or very few) NA players left on NA teams, then NA fans have lost any reason to cheer for their own region, and it will only promote bandwagoning to whichever team is 'best' at the moment, a phenomenon that is already quite present in the fan base.

The country where you have permanent legal residence status should determine your region as a player, with a few possible exceptions, such as Quas who was a NA LCS player before the South American league existed.

hope you understand the average career span of esport players are pretty short, so 2 years is pretty long.

and it isn't exponential growth at all, if anything it would be a steady linear growth of exports becoming local/regional.

Well, I hope you understand that the first non-regional player in the NA LCS was Edward in the second half of season 3, at that time the only extra-regional player. from that point to season five there are more than 20 extra-regional players. A nearly 2000% increase is not linear. But you are right, it will not increase indefinitely, there is a hard cap at which point all team positions will be filled, limiting further growth.
The only EU players were Svenskeren and Kasing.  Doublelift, Hauntzer and Bjergsen and all NA players.

I believe that's only true after the fact

It's like this. Murder is legal today. Starting tomorrow, it's not. You can't get charged for murder if you murdered someone prior to today.
